channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: ‘World Dream’ and Business on Chinese President’s First Overseas Trip
item.description: As Xi Jinping, China’s new leader, headed to Africa after Russia, on his first overseas trip, there was talk back home of a “China Dream” to be shared by the world. And of business.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Workers on a Chinese company's bridge at Kurasini in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. The broad, vehicular bridge will be nearly 700 meters, or 2,300 feet, long.

item.title: Syrians, Fleeing Home, Crowd in Roman Caves
item.description: The Syrian cave dwellers are among the four million people who the United Nations estimates have been forced by the war from their homes.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Ahmed Sheikh’s extended family live in a Roman-era cave in the town of Sarjah.

item.title: The Lede: Interview With Cuban Blogger Yoani Sánchez
item.description: Yoani Sánchez, a Cuban dissident, is on an 80-day international tour after the Cuban government allowed her to leave the country for the first time in a decade.
item.dc:creator: By NATALIE KITROEFF

item.title: Pakistani Cricket Star Tries Again to Turn Adulation Into Political Support
item.description: The star, Imran Khan, kicked off his populist campaign for national elections with a huge rally, hoping to help his political party, which has not won more than a single Parliament seat.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Imran Khan, the leader of Tehreek-e-Insaf, held a rally in Lahore on Saturday. His own popularity has not yet helped his party.

item.title: On Both Sides in Syrian War, Doctors Are Often the Target
item.description: More than 100 physicians have been killed and hundreds more have disappeared into Syrian jails in the last two years.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and HALA DROUBI
item.media:credit: Daniel Etter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Housam Moustafa, a surgeon in training, treated a Syrian rebel at a clinic in Reyhanli, Turkey.

item.title: Boris A. Berezovsky, a Putin Critic, Dies Near London
item.description: Once a close ally of Boris N. Yeltsin who helped install Vladimir V. Putin as president, Boris A. Berezovsky later exiled himself to Britain after a bitter falling-out with the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Boris Berezovsky, the exiled Russian oligarch and long-time opponent of the Kremlin, in London in 2007.

item.title: Russian Ties Put Cyprus Banking Crisis on East-West Fault Line
item.description: With Cyprus’s role as a provider of financial services for Russians, what began as another episode in a familiar narrative has escalated into a drama with geopolitical implications.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: At a rally outside Parliament on Friday to protest the bailout terms, a Russian woman who lives in Cyprus held a sign written in Russian, English and Greek.

item.title: After Violence in Myanmar, a City Counts the Dead
item.description: Army units have restored order to Meiktila, Myanmar, where 32 people have been reported killed and the death toll is expected to rise.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Rebels Push Into Capital in Central African Republic
item.description: There were conflicting reports about a rebel advance on the capital as some said the rebels had entered but witnesses and the president’s spokesman denied it.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: U.S. and Afghanistan Reach Deal on Bagram Prison
item.description: The agreement to transfer control of Bagram Prison to the Afghan government ends a particularly acrimonious chapter of America’s relationship with President Hamid Karzai.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Cyprus Makes Plan to Seize Portion of High-Level Deposits
item.description: Facing a Monday deadline to avoid a banking collapse, Cyprus and its negotiators devised a plan Saturday to take a percentage of savers’ deposits above 100,000 euros to raise money for a bailout.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Cyprus’s president, Nicos Anastasiades, left, met with top Cypriot officials on Wednesday at the presidential palace in Nicosia. He was expected to fly to Brussels late Saturday for meetings.

item.title: News Analysis: Obama Reveals a Knack for Middle East Mediation
item.description: After helping heal a rift between Israel and Turkey, analysts wonder whether President Obama will bring the same doggedness and personal involvement to pursuing peace between Israelis and Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama in Petra, Jordan, on Saturday. He persuaded Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to apologize to Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey for a 2010 raid.

item.title: Hindsight: Deposit Insurance, and the Historical Reasons for It
item.description: The bank turmoil in Cyprus, and previous financial crises elsewhere, are reminders that depositors are also bank creditors, and remain vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: By ROGER LOWENSTEIN
item.media:credit: George Grantham Bain Collection/Library of Congress
item.media:description: A bank run in New York in 1907. The financial turmoil in Cyprus has been a reminder that depositors are creditors of banks and can thus be at risk.

item.title: Colón Struggles as Rest of Panama Races Ahead
item.description: Wedged between a busy port and a handsome cruise ship terminal, Colón is a crowded, cacophonous city of 220,000, with street after street of faded colonial facades.

item.title: Opinion: For Blacks in Cuba, the Revolution Hasn’t Begun
item.description: As the Castro era ends, a four-century legacy of racism lives on.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERTO ZURBANO

item.title: Xi Argues for Closer Cooperation With Russia
item.description: President Xi Jinping of China suggested that the two countries could find common ground as they each seek to claim a place as a respected great power.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China addressed students at the Moscow State Institute of International Relations in Moscow on Saturday.

item.title: France Confirms Death of Abdelhamid Abu Zeid
item.description: President François Hollande says it has been “definitively confirmed” that the regional Al Qaeda leader Abu Zeid, who was reported killed in February in fighting in northern Mali, is dead.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Abdelhamid Abu Zeid was reported killed in late February in fighting in northern Mali.

item.title: Frustrations in Colón, Panama, as Economic Growth Skirts By
item.description: While Panama rides a 9 percent growth rate, joblessness and squalor in Colón, whose black residents say they face racism, appear to only increase.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Wilcox building, once an architectural landmark in Colón, Panama, is now condemned.

item.title: Focus on Benedict Raises Questions on Dual Popes
item.description: Virtually every day highlights the strangeness of the Vatican’s circumstances and brings new debate about what the relationship between the two pontiffs will be.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis, left, and the pope emeritus, Benedict XVI, prayed together at the papal summer residence in Castel Gandolfo, Italy, on Saturday.

item.title: The Lede: Arab Student Explains Why He Heckled Obama in Jerusalem
item.description: The 24-year-old student from Israel’s Arab minority who interrupted President Obama’s speech in Jerusalem on Thursday explained his comments and why he said them in an interview on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Rabbea Eid, 24, was removed by security after interrupting President Obama's speech in Jerusalem on Thursday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Poverty Blamed for Bulgaria’s Suicide Wave
item.description: The economic plight of Bulgaria, one of the European Union’s most impoverished nations, has prompted a wave of public self-immolations and suicides amid protests against corruption and mismanagement.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: The funeral of Plamen Goranov in Varna on March 6.

item.title: Kidnapped Australian Is Freed in Southern Philippines
item.description: Warren Richard Rodwell, who was abducted by members of an Islamic militant organization in 2011, was released early Saturday in the coastal town of Pagadian.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
item.description: A round-up of news from across India.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Filipino Militants Free Australian Hostage
item.description: Al-Qaida-linked militants in the southern Philippines on Saturday released an Australian man near a coastal town where they kidnapped him for ransom 15 months ago.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: March 23
item.description: Cyprus partly approves a formula to obtain a bailout; Israel apologizes to Turkey; the writer Chinua Achebe dies; cargo ships in trouble; and the Malaysian Grand Prix.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Cypriot’s Parliament passed measures to reshape the banking sector, but delayed a vote on a new tax for uninsured deposits.
